article.title: Interstellar Silicon Depletion and the Ultraviolet Extinction

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows observed and model extinction curves for eight different stars. What do the solid red lines represent?
choices: Observed extinction curves based on FM90 and CCM parametrizations.
Model extinction curves based on a mixture of amorphous silicate and graphite.
Extinction from amorphous silicate dust only.

multiple_choice_question.text: These correlation diagrams explore the relationship between silicon depletion ([Si/H]dust) and UV extinction features. What is the main conclusion drawn from these diagrams?
choices: Silicon depletion strongly correlates with both the 2175 ˚A extinction bump and the far-UV extinction rise.
Silicon depletion shows a moderate correlation with the 2175 ˚A extinction bump, but not the far-UV extinction rise.
Silicon depletion shows no significant correlation with either the 2175 ˚A extinction bump or the far-UV extinction rise.
Silicon depletion inversely correlates with both the 2175 ˚A extinction bump and the far-UV extinction rise.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the density-dependent gas-phase carbon abundance ([C/H]gas) fitted by a specific function. What type of function is used for the fitting?
This equation estimates the contribution of silicate dust to the extinction in the visual (V) band (AV). What is the key assumption made in this estimation?
choices: All silicon is locked up in silicate dust grains.
Silicate dust grains have a single size of a = 0.1 µm.
The extinction efficiency of silicate dust is negligible in the UV.
The contribution of carbon dust to AV is dominant.
